image.altText: Leaves in the foreground with a woman sitting out of focus in the background.

items.synopsis: She thought it was a scam phone call, but it was a mother's worst nightmare, her daughter was an alleged victim of a paedophile child care worker.

title.children: When Jane discovered her daughter was the victim of alleged child abuse, she found it hard not to blame herself

image.altText: A digitally altered outline of a woman, standing in front of graphically-altered shattered glass.

items.synopsis: Body-worn-camera footage of former NT Police constable Zachary Rolfe has been shown to the coronial inquest into the death of a high-profile anti-violence campaigner.

title.children: Zachary Rolfe responded to DV call-outs before anti-violence campaigner's murder, inquest hears

image.altText: A cute rat-like animal looks at the camera from a cage. They have a long tail and big ears.

items.synopsis: The federal government says its Darwin housing and gas precinct plans won't threaten native animals. But leading scientists disagree, warning they will hasten population declines of mammals in the Top End.

title.children: The threatened black-footed tree-rat found 'refuge' in Darwin. Now experts fear for its future

image.altText: Lisa Evans and her daugther, both blonde and tanned, smiling in a photo.

items.synopsis: Breast cancer left Lisa Evans about $20,000 out of pocket, but the cost of monitoring her health continues. She is among patients and medical professionals who have contacted the ABC about concerns there is a gender bias in women's healthcare costs.

title.children: Lisa has found the cost of managing cancer 'debilitating'. For her brother, it was a different story

image.altText: Xi Jinping raises his glass and proposes a toast while standing behind a lecturn in front of Chinese flags.

items.synopsis: For much of the past 15 years, China has been developing a weapon that now has become increasingly unstable and that threatens to detonate from within, writes business editor Ian Verrender.

title.children: Turning Japanese: Why China could be heading for a fall

image.altText: Man wearing a suit looks into the camera as he walks into a room, two police officers walking in front of him

items.synopsis: Posting on his social media platform Truth Social, former US president Donald Trump says he plans to turn himself in.

title.children: Trump says he will travel to Georgia to be arrested

image.altText: A map of the world

items.synopsis: The Indian Ocean's version of El Niño — a positive Indian Ocean Dipole — typically brings a reduction in rainfall and an increase in temperatures through winter and spring.

title.children: Hot and dry weather in Australia may soon be the result of another weather event — not just El Niño

image.altText: Men's legs with rainbow socks and football boots

items.synopsis: Not a single elite male AFL player has ever come out publicly as gay or bisexual. This is what happened when Four Corners tried to ask about the silence.

title.children: We tried to tackle the AFL's last great taboo. The code got defensive

image.altText: A man in a suit looks at the camera

items.synopsis: Adam Cranston, the son of former Australian Tax Office deputy commissioner, is jailed for his role in a $105 million tax evasion conspiracy he ran with his sister and three others.

title.children: Son of former ATO deputy commissioner jailed over $105m tax evasion scheme

image.altText: A photo of Satara standing in front of a few buildings. She's wearing an off the shoulder dark red top and black pants.

items.synopsis: Since the pandemic began, Australians are having more spiritual conversations and thinking about mortality more often. So why do many of us consider ourselves not religious?

title.children: Satara left the church during the pandemic. Now she's a 'hopeful agnostic'

image.altText: Bawley Point

items.synopsis: Two communities that went without power during Black Summer are getting a microgrid to keep the lights on during network outages. As another dangerous fire season looms, is this technology the way forward?

title.children: As natural disasters loom, these towns are taking control of their power by building microgrids

image.altText: A close shot of Brereton, who is sitting in the offices of the new national anti--corruption commission

items.synopsis: Finally a reality, the National Anti-Corruption Commission must now prove its worth. And that will be a test not of its design, nor of its powers. It will be a test of leadership, writes Linton Besser.

title.children: Will the new corruption body learn the lessons of the botched Robodebt investigation?

image.altText: Fingal fire on the morning of December 31, 2019.

items.synopsis: Rangers say a bushfire that caused significant environmental damage at the major NT national park was not fuelled by gamba grass. But the local tourism body fears the weed's spread could cause more dangerous bushfires.

title.children: Plea to eradicate highly flammable invasive weed in Litchfield National Park 'before someone gets hurt'

image.altText: Priscilla Atkins in a leafy garden

items.synopsis: The main legal agency responsible for representing Aboriginal clients in the Northern Territory is locked in a legal battle with its former chief executive.

title.children: Aboriginal legal aid service locked in legal battle amid corruption, bullying and forgery allegations

image.altText: Mugshot of a woman with blonde hair

items.synopsis: A judge sentences British nurse Lucy Letby to life in prison for murdering seven babies and attempting to kill six others in a neonatal ward in north-west England.

title.children: 'You have no remorse': British judge sentences baby-killing nurse to life in prison with no chance of parole

image.altText: A woman laying with her baby son.

items.synopsis: Psychologists say struggling new parents are abandoning treatment as they run out of cheaper sessions. The government is being urged to up the number of subsidised sessions to 40.

title.children: 'Absolute desperation': Psychologists write to the Health Minister about the plight of new mums like Rachel

image.altText: President biden descends plane staircase with the first lady

items.synopsis: This morning's news, as it happened.

title.children: Biden arrives in Maui to survey wildfire damage — as it happened

image.altText: pink and yellow glow in the night sky, with blue glowing algae in the water

items.synopsis: Shimmering blue seas below pink and green skies are all possible in Australia's southern-most state which is a nexus for glowing oddities.

title.children: Why Tasmania is a sweet spot for glowing sea, sky and creatures

image.altText: A smiling man wearing a suit embraces a woman wearing a football uniform

items.synopsis: Spanish football federation president Luis Rubiales, who grabbed player Jenni Hermoso's head and gave her an unsolicited kiss on the lips during Women's World Cup victory celebrations, admits it was wrong after initially describing critics as "idiots".

title.children: Spain's football chief apologises for kissing player during World Cup celebrations

image.altText: Coles supermarket sign close up

items.synopsis: Woodside Energy makes a $2.7 billion profit in six months, and Coles profits are up 4.8pc, amid high inflation and cost-of-living pressures. Follow live.

title.children: Woodside Energy posts record $2.7b half-year profit, Coles profits up 4.8pc, but BHP profits down 37pc

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian share market is having another lacklustre day after its worst weekly performance in a year last week as investors worry about China and more possible rate rises in the US. The ASX 200 is down 0.1 per cent to 7,108 with consumer firms and energy stocks leading the sector losses. Technology stocks have rallied today after strong results from software firm Altium which saw revenue surge by 19 per cent over the year to June to $US263 million, with a 15 per cent rise in the final dividend payout. BHP (-1.5 per cent) and Coles are weighing on the market with investors disappointed with their profit results. Best and worst performers on the ASX 200: Altium +27.5% Megaport +21.75% Hub24 +15.1% Nanosonics -6.2% NIB -6.1% Coles -6%
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX  in the red at midday

children.content: The Australian share market is having another lacklustre day after its worst weekly performance in a year last week as investors worry about China and more possible rate rises in the US.
The ASX 200 is down 0.1 per cent to 7,108 with consumer firms and energy stocks leading the sector losses.

Technology stocks have rallied today after strong results from software firm Altium which saw revenue surge by 19 per cent over the year to June to $US263 million, with a 15 per cent rise in the final dividend payout.
BHP (-1.5 per cent) and Coles are weighing on the market with investors disappointed with their profit results.
Best and worst performers on the ASX 200:
Altium +27.5%
Megaport +21.75%
Nanosonics -6.2%
Coles -6%

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Oil and gas producer Woodside Energy has seen half-year net profit jump to a record $US1.74 billion ($2.71 billion) after it bought BHP's petroleum business. That comes after record half-year production of 91.3 million barrels of oil equivalent, and despite a fall in oil prices. Investors get an interim dividend of $US0.80 a share, down 27 per cent from the same time last year. Woodside says development of its major growth project, Scarborough, off the north-west coast of WA, is nearly 40 per cent complete. Chief executive Meg O'Neill says Woodside is continuing to investigate the death of a worker at its North Rankin platform in June, the first fatality at an offshore platform in Australia in more than ten years. “We have implemented changes to our operational practices based on the preliminary findings of those  investigations and shared our learnings with the broader industry," Ms O'Neill said. “Woodside’s safety performance over the past two years has been below the standard we set for ourselves.  We know we must do better and are resolved to strive for a return to leading safety performance."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Woodside profit jumps to record high

children.content: Oil and gas producer Woodside Energy has seen half-year net profit jump to a record $US1.74 billion ($2.71 billion) after it bought BHP's petroleum business.
That comes after record half-year production of 91.3 million barrels of oil equivalent, and despite a fall in oil prices.
Investors get an interim dividend of $US0.80 a share, down 27 per cent from the same time last year.
Woodside says development of its major growth project,
Scarborough
, off the north-west coast of WA, is nearly 40 per cent complete.

Chief executive Meg O'Neill says Woodside is continuing to investigate the death of a worker at its North Rankin platform in June, the first fatality at an offshore platform in Australia in more than ten years.
“We have implemented changes to our operational practices based on the preliminary findings of those  investigations and shared our learnings with the broader industry," Ms O'Neill said.

“Woodside’s safety performance over the past two years has been below the standard we set for ourselves.  We know we must do better and are resolved to strive for a return to leading safety performance."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Coles Group has reported its profits for 2023. It's posted a 4.8% increase in full-year profit, to $1.09 billion. Its financial results: Net profit after tax: up 4.8%, to $1.09 billion Sales revenue: up 5.9% to $40.5 billion EBITDA: up 3.8% to $3.38 billion Interim dividend per share: 36 cents Final dividend per share: 30 cents Total dividend per share: 66 cents James Graham, Coles Group chairman: "It is pleasing to record continuing sales growth and broadly stable after-tax profits from continuing operations in another year market by challenging operations. "The payment of a steady final dividend of 30 cents per share is in line with our 80 to 90 per cent full year dividend payout policy." The company achieve fourth-quarter sales growth of 8% in supermarkets and 2.9% in liquor.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Coles profits up 4.8% to $1.09 billion

children.content: Coles Group has reported its profits for 2023.
It's posted a
4.8% increase in full-year profit
, to
$1.09 billion.
Its financial results:
Net profit after tax: up 4.8%, to $1.09 billion
Sales revenue: up 5.9% to $40.5 billion
EBITDA: up 3.8% to $3.38 billion
Interim dividend per share: 36 cents
Final dividend per share: 30 cents
Total dividend per share: 66 cents
James Graham, Coles Group chairman:
"It is pleasing to record continuing sales growth and broadly stable after-tax profits from continuing operations in another year market by challenging operations.
"The payment of a steady final dividend of 30 cents per share is in line with our 80 to 90 per cent full year dividend payout policy."
The company achieve fourth-quarter sales growth of 8% in supermarkets and 2.9% in liquor.

image.altText: Artist Tank, wearing a black hoodie and dark beanie, stands in front of a wall mural.

items.synopsis: Art and legal experts say copyright infringements online are on the rise and one of the contemporary art world's greatest challenges.

title.children: Australian artist says 'creativity not valued' as Temu steals his design, sells it online for less than $7

image.altText: a man looks at a picture frame

items.synopsis: Corrie Luk wishes voluntary assisted dying had been an option during the last stage of his wife Keery's spiral into dementia. Tragic memories of her death spur him on in the fight to amend the state's euthanasia laws.

title.children: After watching his wife die of dementia, Corrie wants WA's voluntary assisted dying laws changed

image.altText: Peter Dutton wearing a blue suit and light pink tie standing in front of a brick building that is out of focus

items.synopsis: The opposition leader says many of the traumatic scenes he witnessed during his time in the Queensland police force have stayed with him, as they do for many current and former officers.

title.children: How Peter Dutton's policing career led to 'siege mentality' approach to parenting

image.altText: A US dollar note is pictured alongside an Australian 10 dollar and 20 dollar bill.

items.synopsis: For foreign tourists? Great. For travellers? Terrible. For the economy? A mix. The fall in the Australian dollar has created winners and losers across the economy.

title.children: The Aussie dollar could slump below 60 US cents, bringing with it pain and gain

image.altText: A woman sits at a bench, with a shopping trolley.

items.synopsis: New data shows exactly how much the average cost of some of the most common grocery items have gone up and down in the last year. And the price tags on basic items, like canned tuna and beans, are among those increasing.

title.children: These are the everyday shoppers feeling the brunt of skyrocketing food prices

image.altText: A photo of the blurred back of a man's head and shoulders. The picture looks at someone sitting at a bench in the d

items.synopsis: There are fears the university sector's highly casualised workforce is preventing people from reporting experiences of sexual violence at work.

title.children: University staff urged to come forward with experiences of sexual harassment and assault

image.altText: Electricians place solar panels on roof

items.synopsis: In some cases, adding a battery to your rooftop solar system will pay off. But to be sure, households need information about many factors — and there's no single reliable place to find it, write Asma Aziz and Daryoush Habibi.

title.children: Is it worth investing in a battery for your rooftop solar? Here's what you need to know before you buy

image.altText: Paul Smith grocery shopping in the vegetable section of the supermarket

items.synopsis: Ideal growing conditions this year have seen the volume of vegetables in one of Australia's largest winter production regions skyrocket, leading to oversupply and low farmgate prices.

title.children: Queensland farmers have grown too many vegetables, but who's to blame?

image.altText: A grey and white image shows craters and ridges on the surface of the moon.

items.synopsis: India launched a Moon rocket for less than the cost of a Hollywood space film and it's sent back new pictures of the far side of the lunar surface as it looks for a safe place to land.

title.children: Indian lunar rocket looking for safe landing place, systems working 'perfectly'

image.altText: Thaksin Shinawatra with his sister Yingluck on a plane

items.synopsis: The return of a billionaire fugitive will set the stage for one of the most dramatic days in Thai political history. Here's what you need to know about former prime minister Thaksin Shinawatra.

title.children: The billionaire patriarch of Thailand's fabled political dynasty has returned home to be arrested. Here's why

image.altText: Woman in white and black striped shirt wearing black hat standing on sand dune

items.synopsis: In remote far-western Queensland lies an ancient gorge, scattered with rock carvings, that's rarely visited. Traditional owners fear it could fall victim to the world's insatiable appetite for critical minerals.

title.children: 'We're an afterthought': Traditional owners fear repeat of Juukan Gorge disaster in outback Queensland

image.altText: Murrandoo Yanner Jnr has short dark hair and a beard

items.synopsis: After numerous "once in a generation" disasters, a new summit suggests Indigenous expertise could help us better prepare for times of crisis.

title.children: 'They know this country': Push for First Nations knowledge-leaders to help guide natural disaster relief

image.altText: A young girl lying in a hospital bed

items.synopsis: Police charge a 49-year-old woman over a hit-and-run crash in Perth's southern suburbs that left 12-year-old Alexis Lloyd with serious injuries.

title.children: Woman charged over hit-and-run crash that left schoolgirl with broken leg and collarbone

image.altText: Two people in orange suits sit in chairs in a white hospital room

items.synopsis: An independent auditor is brought in over concerns specialist equipment may have been removed from the Royal Hobart Hospital's hyperbaric unit, but determines there's no way to know if — or what — items were taken.

title.children: Fears medical equipment taken from $11m hyperbaric unit, documents show
